description: Darkness-bearer Jackie Estacado slips off to Alaska, land of the midnight sun, to escape the all-encompassing darkness. But his trip takes a sour turn when Jackie is confronted by a soul even more tortured than his own...and more powerful. With no darkness to sustain him, how can Jackie face...the Reckoning? Â
name: The Reckoning

description:
Fairchild with company set to rescue Grunge from being clueless as a sacrifice to the Coda Amazons. Rainmaker and Daphne also set to retrieve their allies through espionage while Burnout and Freefall manage to intervene saving Grunge with some of their pirate buddies from last issue.

Wildcats team only appears in the backup story "Robot Ruckus, Part 3"
name: Family Feud / Robot Ruckus, Part 3
Ascending Evil Part 2

description: Nazis offer lady Death the soul of the cat goddess. Vampirella comes back from the beyond. Vampirella beats Lady Death, releases Pantha. Lady Death is disappointed and teams up with Pantha and Vampirella to defeat the nazis. Dixie gets shot into the back and dies.
name: The End

description: Pantha turns to panther and regains her memory of who she is. Vampi uses the distraction to get herself free. Pendragon has been captured by the nazi bikers. Vampirella and Pantha drive through the wall with bikes and save the day.
name: Death Valley, Part 2: Helter Skelter

description: Vampirella spirit traveled back in time. Pantha has no idea who she is. Vampi loans the scarab from her to study. Pantha gets in trouble, vampirella flys to the rescue. Vampirella gets shot, and when she wakes up, her limbs have been tied to different motorcycles and they start to ride.
name: Death Valley, Part 1: Sympathy for the Devil

description: Timm, the creative genius behind the Batman animated series, does Vampirella! Timm and fan-favorite writer Ty Templeton contribute a bonus story to Vampirella's 30th Anniversary celebration! Super-mega-bonus! The issue also contains the Earth-Shattering conclusion to the "Rebirth" storyline, written by David Conway and Steven Grant, artwork by Patrick Zircher. Featuring an awesome cover by Jae Lee.
name: Lust For Life; Rebirth, Part 3
Ascending Evil Part 1
Looking For Mr. Goodwin; Rebirth, Part 1

description: this story continues in Vampirella issue #0
name: Hell on Earth, Part 3

description: A Vampirella/Shi crossover.
name: Queen's Gambit 3 Last Blood

description: A Vampirella/Shi crossover.
name: Queen's Gambit Part 2
Holy War, Part 3: Day of Wrath!

description: Wizard World Exclusive, the tragic events of Final Crisis are foretold.Â  As an interview with super-star writer Grant Morrison, and art J.G. Jones.Â  Give you the inside scoop on what will actually be the Final Crisis in the Detective Comic Universe!

1. The Boy Tycoon of Smallville (Superboy)
  2. Bebe (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  3. The Great Kryptonite Hunt! (Superboy, Kryptonite, Lana Lang)
  4. Jerry the Jitterbug (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  5. Nervous Norman (gag strip)
  6. Navy Notes (full text article)
  7. The Boy with Superboy Powers! (Superboy)

First Comics Code Authority issue.

"It's okay, Superboy! I can catch this piece of falling masonry without any help!"
name: The Boy with Superboy Powers!

description:
1. The Six Jimmy Olsens (Jimmy Olsen, Superman, Lois Lane, Perry White / written by Otto Binder)
  2. The Stolen Superman Signal (Jimmy Olsen, Superman / written by Otto Binder) -Â Jimmy is chosen to gather charity donation collections since his signal watch allows him to summon Superman making him safer and cheaper than an armored car. But one criminal has found a way around this problem.
  3. Jack the Giant-Wrecker (full page article by Joe Maxwell)
  4. Jerry Jitterbug (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  5. Jimmy Olsen's Super Illusions (Jimmy Olsen, Superman / written by Otto Binder)Â
name: Jimmy Olsen's Super-Illusions

description: Just when he thought it was safe to come back to New York City, mobster Jackie Estacado finds himself face to face with...the Angelus! Yes, the Darkness' oldest and most deadly nemesis is back and this time she won't stop until either she or Jackie is dead. And if that wasn't bad enough, another mortal enemy has returned to battle Estacado...The Magdalena! Â
name: All In The Family - Part 1 of 3

description: The Three Sandmen starring The Sandman, script by Larry Dean, art by Bert Christman; Wes joins up with two of his former service buddies to discover if Teeter Sneed has a hand in the killing of several of their old chums and threatening to do the same to several others. The Suicide of Major Duval: Part 5 starring Barry O'Neill, script and art by Ed Winiarski. Cal Grant's Payroll Robbery starring the Federal Men, script by Jerry Siegel, art by Wayne Boring. The Fiddler and the Bank Robbers: Part 2 starring Jack Woods, script and art by Jim Chambers. The Flying Dutchman: Part 3 starring Socko Strong, script and art by Joseph Sulman [signed as Koppy]. Professor Doolittle humor two-pager by Bob Kane. Revolt of the Thugs: Part 2 starring Captain Desmo, script and art by Ed Winiarski. Admiral Cato's Underwater Base--Anchors Aweigh!, script and art by Bart Tumey. Kidnapping in the Orient starring Skip Schuyler, script and art by Tom Hickey. The Menace of Chen Fu: Part 2 starring Rusty and His Pals, script and art by Bob Kane. In the Pit of Dagan starring Cotton Carver, script by Gardner F. Fox, art by Ogden Whitney.
name: On the Waterfront

description: What could drive a Christian youth minister to head out into the spiritually uncharted territories of Southern Africa? A little something called revenge...
name: Head, Part 2

description: Lauren is the new girl in the mall-and-beach town of San Narciso, California, and though this is her third high school in two years, she's determined to call this one home. But it's not easy finding a place among the cliques of the high-school social hierarchy...especially when the popular girls have super-powers! And what mystery lies beneath the school?
name: Girl Power

description:
Collects issues #62-68. Just when things seem to be settling down for our heroines, Black Canary is sent to China on a mission of mercy and runs into the DC Universe's most deadly combatant: Lady Shiva! But it turns out Shiva has an agenda of her own, while making Canary an offer that could change the course of her life. Meanwhile, Oracle's personal life is a shambles-and now, her work seems to be as well-as the information she feeds out to her various heroes starts going strangely and dangerously awry! With The Huntress also stumbling upon some of Oracle's secrets, can The Birds hope to stick together?

This Trade Paperback collects Birds of Prey issues:

Birds of Prey #62

Birds of Prey #63

Birds of Prey #64

Birds of Prey #65

Birds of Prey #66

Birds of Prey #67

Birds of Prey #68
name: Sensei and Student

volume.name: Birds of Prey: Sensei and Student

description:
Continuing directly from the pages of NEW AVENGERS #37: The Hood's gang of super-criminals takes the fight right to the Avengersâ door!! Its wall-to-wall action and the end of an era for one Avenger and a major defection for another. This double-sized issue ties into or wraps up threads from Civil War, World War Hulk, both Avengers titles and the upcoming Secret Invasion!! Avengers writer Bendis welcomes rising star Carlo Pagulayan on his Avengers debut...

Maria Hill recieves word of the break-in at the Raft. When she sees the list of those missing, she realizes that it's every single person they just brought in from the "bank think in Jersey." The Raft wasn't prepared for a mystical break out.

In Tigra's apartment, she is visited by the Hood and some of his new teammates. Holding a gun to her head, he demands to know where the "new" Avengers are otherwise he will kill her and her mother. She says they are in Dr. Strange's house. Even though it appears to be boarded up, everyone in the Initiative knows that's where they are. They just can't prove it. She tells them in the hopes that they will go and get their butts kicked.

At Dr. Strange's Sanctum Sanctorium, Jessica, Danielle, and the Night Nurse are enjoying some tea and gossip. The team arrives from a successful mission. They're all beat. Suddenly Dr. Strange collapses and orders no one to touch him. Outside, The Hood and all the bad guys he's gathered stand waiting to attack. They're still not sure if the Avengers are really there. The Hood tries using his powers to peer through the illusion. Then Spider-Man is spotted leaving. As soon as he's out, his spider-sense goes off and he rushes back. Yelling, "They're Here!" no one knows who exactly he's talking about. He grabs Danielle and takes off. Luke has no idea what Spider-Man is doing and gets ready to follow him. Clint notices that the protection seal on Strange's place is turning into leaves. Chemistro was able to change the properties of it. Jessica catches up to Spider-Man and her daughter, cursing the whole way. He tells her there was no time to explain. He tells her to take Danielle and get as far away as possible.

Inside, the Avengers think they are still under Strange's spell that prevents outsiders from seeing or hearing them. The gunshots directed at them tell them otherwise. The Hood enters and shoots Strange several times in the chest as he lies on his bed. Wong takes on the Hood. Jigsaw gets Jessica and Danielle in the sights of a sniper rifle. He is stopped by Spider-Man. Night Nurse tells Wong that Stephen isn't breathing. Luke is outright ticked off that they came after his baby.

As the fight is setting off fireworks, S.H.I.E.L.D. agents become aware that something is going down. The Hood is about to shoot Iron Fist from behind when he is attacked by Tigra. Night Nurse tells Wong they need to call someone. Stephen is dead. Then his eyes light up. Getting up slowly, he tells them (again) not to touch him. It looks like the Avengers are simply too outnumbered. Strange appears, growing larger and begins chanting some mystical spells. Everyone in the room is frozen in a painful scream. Wong is speechless after witnessing this. Night Nurse tries going to Stephen, who is unresponsive. Wong finds a book he was looking for. Going to each Avenger, he says a chant and touches each one. Painfully, they awaken.

Stephen begins to explain what he has done. Lately he has used darker magics. He was arrogant and thought he could handle them. He says he has failed them as he had failed helping Bruce Banner. He can no longer be the Sorcerer Supreme. He has to atone for what he's done. Apologizing again, he says he has to leave. WIth some waves of his hands, he disappears.

Ms. Marvel and her Operation: Lightning Storm agents arrive. She asks where Jessica and the baby are. Luke says he's not sure, out there somewhere. Carol, reluctantly, tells him to go find them. Surprised that she's not going to arrest them, she then calls the helicarrier requesting Brother Voodoo and a clean up crew to take care of all the bad guys. She's asked what about the rebel Avengers. She says they got away. She turns to her agents telling them that's what happened. One argues that he can't go along with it. She reminds him that she's stronger than he is. Luke thanks her. She asks what they'll do next. He has no idea.

The Hood managed to escape. Talking to himself (or maybe his demon) he says he did everything he was told to do. Then he says that now he knows how to stop them.

Outside Stark Tower, Jessica, with Danielle crying in her arms, desperately tries to get someone to let her in. She's ready to register in order to protect her daughter.
name: The Trust, Pt.  7

description:
1. Cover by Curt Swan and George Klein.
  2. "Krypton Lives Again!" (part 1) "Krypton's Second Doom!" (part 2) written by Otto Binder, penciled and inked by Wayne Boring. A planet comes crashing towards Earth; that planet is Krypton?!
  3. The Policeman Is Your Friend! (public service message written by Jack Schiff)
  4. "Cap's Hobby Hints" gag strip by Henry Boltinoff.

Note: All Kryptonian characters are androids.

Flashback to Superman #141.

Superman (thought): This is Krypton, where I was born. But I've brought the touch of death to all my people. The only survivor is my dog Krypto...and he doesn't remember me!
name: Krypton Lives Again!

description:
Bart Simpson in Space?! Join the intrepid boy of action as he finds galactic turmoil, political unrest, and three-eyed giants while accompanied by the whole Simpson family on a mission to explore the nether-regions of the cosmos! Back on the planet, in another earthbound story, Lisa wins a date with not one, but two boy bands. Then, in another tall tale of science, Bart defies death and gravity with a new invention by Professor Frink that's not quite ready for the patent office!

  1. Terror On Trioculon! (The Space Family Simpson vs the Trioculons : a parody of Lost in Space)
  2. Battle Of The Boy-Bands! (starring Lisa Simpson)
  3. Sky-High Bart! (Professor Frink's Partly Probable Parables : Bart wants to be taller, will Profeesor Frink's boots be what Bart needs?)
  4. Bart's People
name: Troublemaker

description: 1. Lisa's Adventures in Wordland (like Alice in Wonderland, Simpson-style) -- 2. Footnotes & Annotations (full text) -- 3. The Secret Life of Lisa Simpson (The Bongo Beat : full text article by Matt Groening) -- 4. Pony Express (letters and fan art) -- 5. Bongo Profile: Mili Smythe
name: Lisa's Adventures in Wordland

description: "The Red Hood has Onyx on her heels, but Batman's still in Metropolis! Can the Dark Knight get back to Gotham in time to save the urban heroine from the city's latest costumed psycho killer?"
name: Family Reunion, Conclusion: Face To Face

description:
1. Love is Blind! (Love is Blind! part 1) -- 2. The Blind Beauty and the Beast! (Love is Blind! part 2)

"Lois lane used to be Superman's girlfriend... how could she fall in love with that... monstrosity!"
name: Love Is Blind! : Beauty and the Beast!

(Cerebus and Elrod are signing autographs, then Bran suggests Cerebus run for Prime Minister and Astoria actually sees if he can do it) -- 3. Welcome To Hell, Dr. Franklin (part of "Welcome to heaven, Dr. Franklin" / by William Messner-Loebs) -- 4. Aardvark Comment (letters) -- 5. Cerebus ; Master of Kung Fu (promotional pin-up : Gene Day also pencils and inks)

(Superboy / written by Jerry Coleman) -- 5. Jerry Jitterbug (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff) -- 6. Adventure in the Skies (full text article by Jack Miller) -- 7. The Magic Necklace! (Superboy, Lana Lang, Prof. Lang : "Oh, you don't have to bother, Superboy! Those spears can't harm me as long as I'm wearing this charm! / written by Alvin Schwartz) -- 8. Bebe (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
name: The Magic Necklace! ; The Boy of Clay! ; School for Geniuses!

description:
1. The Feats of Chief Super-Duper (Jimmy Olsen, Superman / written by Otto Binder)

  2. The Case of the Careless Camper! (public service message by Peter Porkchops / written by Jack Schiff)

  3. The Meek Jimmy Olsen (Jimmy Olsen, Superman, Lois Lane / written by Otto Binder)

  4. Professor Eureka (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)

  5. Skooter

  6. I Chased a Runaway Blimp (full text story by Joe Mabely)

  7. The Boy Superman (Jimmy Olsen, Superman, Lois, Perry White, Daily Planet / written by Otto Binder) When Jimmy dons Superman's costume, some hillbillies think he's Superman and wants him to marry one of the locals!

"My hero-- Superman! He scared the b'ar clean outta the cave! Jimmy Olsen (thought): it wasn't I--it was the skunk! But these back-woods folk think I'm Superman because I'm wearing this suit!
name: The Boy Superman!

description: A WIZARD Exclusive. Â Â It reviews the story, and the direction of the series.
name: Preview
How Santa Got His Red Suit

description:
The Initiative's biggest secret hasn't come back to haunt them, it's come back to KILL THEM! Blood will run, heads will roll, and this time "dead" means DEAD! Say goodbye to at LEAST one regular cast member as KILLED IN ACTION starts racking up its body count. You know, maybe this WASN'T such a good time for TASKMASTER, ANT-MAN, and the new recruits to sign upâ¦"

Picking up from the end of last issue, a small Hank Pym stands before a recruit with the Tactigon on his arm. Hank orders him to lower the weapon so they can talk. He just tells him he's on his lists and fires at Hank. Hank apparently is blown away. The kid walks away and says, "Henry Pym, a.k.a. Yellow Jacket...Killed In Action."

Flashback to earlier that day. Taskmaster is putting the new recruits to the test. he's actually mopping the floor with them. Crusader simply stands back. When Taskmaster asks him why he isn't taking part in the exercise, he replies that the smart thing to do is admit they don't stand a chance or wait until someone else gets in a lucky shot. Taskmaster is impressed with this logic. The truth is Crusader is a Skrull and doesn't want to risk getting knocked out and be revealed.

In the Infirmary, Trauma is sitting with Cloud 9. He's trying to help her through having shot a Hydra agent. Changing his appearance as the agent, Cloud 9 is able to talk to him and apologize for killing him. Beast and Moonstar observe and are impressed with Trauma's newfound therapist abilities.

In the Weapons Cache, Hank Pym and Henry Gyrich enter the vault containing the Tactigon. Gyrich isn't happy with the weapon just sitting there.

In the lab, Baron Von Blitzschlag is working with another MVP clone. The clone claims he is Michael Van Patrick. The Baron says he can't use that name since one of the other clones is already using the name in Kentucky. He suggests going by Van Patrick's middle name but the clone won't budge.

Hank comes in with the Tactigon. He brings it to the clone and asks if he's willing to try it out. As it bonds to him, he gets a flashback to when MVP was shot and killed. He is able to access the classified data on what really happened. Seeing that "he" was killed in action, he loses his mind. The Baron is smashed against the wall as Hank grows to a large size. That just makes him a bigger target for the Tactigon. Before the clone can finish him off, Hank shrinks down and runs away. The clone then smashes the other clones sitting in the lab tubes. He carves on his chest the letters, "KIA."

Back in the Combat Simulator, the recruits are still being tested by Taskmaster. KIA smashes through a wall. The recruits see this as their opportunity to unite and be on the other end of a beating. That's not the case. They are soon all unconscious. An alarm is sent throughout the base. KIA is about to deal with Taskmaster when he excuses himself for a moment. From the other room Taskmaster can hear, "Yellowjacket. You're on my list," followed by a big zap.

KIA returns to Taskmaster. He asks if he's on his list too. KIA thinks and says no. He leaves them alone and Taskmaster tries to help Crusader find his missing hand.

Trauma and Thor Girl stumble upon KIA. Trauma is surprised because he knows MVP is dead. KIA tells him he's on his list. Thor Girl stands in front of Trauma as KIA fires. She doesn't take the hit so well. Enraged, Trauma transforms into what he thinks will scare him. He's actually become the one thing the Tactigon is afraid of. The problem is, KIA isn't afraid of it. The Tactigon transforms into a blade and goes right through Trauma.

Next is Gauntlet, who is still in a coma in the infirmary. Going to his bed, KIA finds the bed empty.

In the Weapons Cache, someone rips off the door to the vault. Gauntlet grabs an alien sword. Speaking the alien language, he is ready for action.
name: First Casualties

description:
Overview

Can Matt Murdock balance the scales of justice and save his wife? Can Daredevil bring peace to the streets of Hell's Kitchen, which are caught in a super-powered gang war? And what is the terrible secret Mr. Fear is hiding? By Brubaker and Lark.
name: Without Fear, Part Five of Six

description: Matthew Bright took the name of Brendan Miller and began his career as a police officer. But his real identity may be a problem.
name: Bright

description: The Three Sandmen starring The Sandman, script by Larry Dean, art by Bert Christman; Wes joins up with two of his former service buddies to discover if Teeter Sneed has a hand in the killing of several of their old chums and threatening to do the same to several others. The Suicide of Major Duval: Part 5 starring Barry O'Neill, script and art by Ed Winiarski. Cal Grant's Payroll Robbery starring the Federal Men, script by Jerry Siegel, art by Wayne Boring. The Fiddler and the Bank Robbers: Part 2 starring Jack Woods, script and art by Jim Chambers. The Flying Dutchman: Part 3 starring Socko Strong, script and art by Joseph Sulman [signed as Koppy]. Professor Doolittle humor two-pager by Bob Kane. Revolt of the Thugs: Part 2 starring Captain Desmo, script and art by Ed Winiarski. Admiral Cato's Underwater Base--Anchors Aweigh!, script and art by Bart Tumey. Kidnapping in the Orient starring Skip Schuyler, script and art by Tom Hickey. The Menace of Chen Fu: Part 2 starring Rusty and His Pals, script and art by Bob Kane. In the Pit of Dagan starring Cotton Carver, script by Gardner F. Fox, art by Ogden Whitney.

description:
This issue opens with a short explanation about hell. Itâs hot, pretty humid, more or less what youâd expect, but what you might not expect is that the sun and moon are both out side by side 24/7. Among other things, it leaves werewolves in a sort of half-man/half-beast limbo, and vampires feel a constant mix of euphoria and the sense of being about to explode in a ball of flame. Demons from the Primordium Age, even those that have had their powers reduced, like Illyria, donât seem to be affected. That brings us to the current situation where Illyria is throwing Angel all through Spikeâs mansion. Angel recaps for Illyria, telling her that a Lord was killed and primordial Sandskrit was found on the scene and that was why he came looking for her. While theyâre fighting (basically just Illyria beating up Angel) they seem to be going through time. This time traveling disorients Angel but Illyria just keeps attacking, even saying sheâll take him apart and throw all his pieces in different directions. He says he wants to talk but when she doesnât stop hitting him he grabs up some steak knives and stabs her in the hip. Annoyed, she pulls it out and he goes for a gun lying near a dead cop on the ground. When he turns to shoot her sheâs standing with the knives and she tells him to shoot. He again says he doesnât want to fight and Illyria rushes him and crucifies him to the wall before sending them skittering backwards and forwards through time and bringing them back. When the fight is over Spike gets Illyria to refrain from killing Angel for the moment. She still wants to do it but Spike is talking her out of it when something new comes into the picture. Angel hears flapping leathery wings and then his dragon sticks his head through a wall and into the house where Illyria, Angel and Spike are.

Illyria sees the new enemy and is so ready for a real fight that she leaves Angel where he is (after stabbing him in the side for good measure) that she walks over to the dragon and offers him the first strike. The dragon accepts the offer and shoots a ball of flame that hurls Illyria across the room. After a momentâs pause she rises to her feat and says âmore.â While Illyria goes to fight the dragon Spike gathers up Angel and takes him outside. Spike finds out that Angel knew where he was the whole time and demands to know who else does. Before he gives a real answer the fight between Illyria and the dragon spills out onto Spikeâs lawn where the two vampires are standing. As Spike is talking about how badly Angel has messed things up, the dragon eats Illyria. Seconds later he spits her out, destroying the fountain of blood in the process. Spike tells Angel that when Illyriaâs done fighting he and the dragon need to leave, but Angel says he wonât leave until Spike tells him what he knows. Spike starts saying that Angel has no idea what heâs doing when Connor comes along and agrees with him, saying that Spike and Illyria had nothing to do with the death of Krâph, the runes or the murders, because they donât put innocents in danger. The reason he knows that is because Spike is on his side. Spike and Illyria send him about half of the humans that theyâre hiding. Because of those two, theyâve saved so many humans that the overflow is staying in Spikeâs house. Connor shows him all this and Angel decides itâs time to leave.

Back at the offices of Wolfram and Hart, Wesley is standing around unable to touch anything. When Angel comes in Wesley tells him that he needs to lay low, but Angel has other things in mind. He lets Wesley know that whoever killed the Lord of Westwood pinned it on Spike, but doesnât tell him about Illyria. He gets one of his swords and says something about changing the game.

Elsewhere, the Lords of LA (except for the Lord of Silverlake, the Lord of Beverly Hills and of course the Lord of Westwood) are meeting. The Lord of Compton says they should kill the Lord of Beverly Hills, but the Lord of Burbank talks him out of trying to take her on. Burge calls the meaning to order, getting to the point of why they are gathered, to figure out the best way to kill Angel. The Lord of Weho tells him that Wolfram and Hart warned them not to kill him but Burge says he doesnât care. At that moment Angel himself waltzes into the middle of their meeting and tells them to bring the fight if they want one. He even gets Wesley to tell that that Wolfram and Hart say they can if they want to. With no higher power protecting him, Angel challenges Burge, saying that if he wins their fight, he owns Downtown LA. Burge turns down the direct challenge but says heâll have a champion fight for him at a later date. Angel spreads the challenge to all the Lords. They accept, all of them leaving the fight to their champions, and they set the fight for two days later. As Angel leaves his thoughts go to the fact that the sun and moon of hell donât alter a vampireâs healing abilities so a vampire with all the wounds Angel has recently sustained would be healed up in time. The only thing is, Angel is no longer a vampire.
name: Chapter Three

description: "The Mad Hatter's implant is driving Killer Croc-well, mad! Can Batman save the reptilian rogue before he shreds himself into an early grave? And can the Dark Knight save the Hatter from bloody, bestial retribution?"
name: Breaking the Skin : Into the Jaws of Killer Croc!

description:
The wascally wabbit has bought the farm, and every creature who's ever been tricked, blasted, double-crossed, outmaneuvered and generally bugged by Bugs is under suspicion!

A landmark 75th issue finds Bugs Bunny dead? Yes, it's true - the wascally wabbit has bought the farm, and every creature who's ever been tricked, blasted, double-crossed, out-maneuvered and generally bugged by Bugs is under suspicion. Daffy sets out to find the culprit, because it's a terrible, awful, horrible, no good, very bad thing and, well because he's the prime suspect. This special issue is jam-packed with all the mugs, goons and ninnies from all the years of classic Warner Bros. cartoons. Will Daffy be able to pick the right one out of the lineup?
name: Who Killed Bugs? : A Hare Gone Conclusion

description: The stunning conclusion of the most important chapter of Black Adam's life! All will be revealed as the magic word that has eluded him for so long comes to light, and the final fate of Isis is revealed.

1. Writing -- 2. The Insecure Sinecure -- 3. The Countess and the Aardvark -- 4. The Origin of the Wolveroach -- 5. Origin of the Wolveroach Part 2: The Why and The Are -- 6. Origin of the Wolveroach Part 3: The Mystic We -- 7. Suddenly, Sophia -- 8. All Lined Up -- 9. Carroll E King Reads -- 10. Memoirs -- 11. Note -- 12. First Impression -- 13. Tree Planting -- 14. Approved By -- 15. Rough Pope --16. Sophia -- 17. Henrot-Gutch -- 18. Astoria -- 19. Elf -- 20. Theresa -- 21. Stormy Weather -- 22. Cerebus Was -- 23. Something Cerebus Was -- 24. Mrs. Tynsdale-Clyde's Tea -- 25. Powers -- 26. Boom -- 27. Appointments -- 28. Mind Game IV -- 29. Never Pray For Change -- 30. Anything Done For The First Time Unleashes a Demon -- 31. Thrill of Agony and the Victory of Defeat -- 32. Day of Greatness, Age of Consent -- 33. Another Thing Coming -- 34. Ignore It, It's Just Another Reality -- 35. Sane As It Ever Was -- 36. Hovering Below the Fray -- 37. Time Passes and Life Manoeuvres -- 38. Fascination and Fruition -- 39. Acquired Tastes -- 40. Terrible Analogies -- 41. Varying Reasons of Assorted Depths -- 42. Odd Transformations -- 43. Odd Transformations Part 2 -- 44. Spinning Straw Into Gold -- 45. Causality Casualty

Church and State is volume three of the Cerebus the Aardvark series and picks up right where High Society leaves off. To compound matters further, this reprint volume is part one of a two-part story that is self-contained within the larger framework.

A face from Cerebus's past returns with an offer he can't refuse. But the gray one has learned a few lessons from the powers that be and turns the tables on the would-be puppet masters. This volume also marks the addition of Gerhard as a background artist, and the artwork begins to create a visual impact equal to the creative impact of the comic book's ideas and stories. The storytelling also becomes subtler, the beginning of a stylistic trademark in Cerebus that leads the reader to believe more action is taking place peripherally than in the actual pages. High points include a two-part dream sequence, which is visually unparalleled in the history of comic art; a pee-break which is unrivaled in length in the history of comic art; the return of Jaka; and "the baby incident." Don't forget to pick up Church and State, Volume Two , as volume one ends with the cruelest of cliffhangers. This is the Ivan the Terrible of graphic novels, both in terms of its subject matter and the creative peak it represents for the author.
name: Church & State Volume I

description:
A collection of reprints and a jam between Dave and Chester Brown

  1. The Name of the Game is Diamondback (reprinted from Swords of Cerebus #1) -- 2. The Morning After (Reprinted from Swords of Cerebus #2) -- 3. What Happened Between Issues 20 and 21 (reprinted from Swords of Cerebus #3) -- 4. Magiking (reprinted from Swords of Cerebus #4) -- 5. Silverspoon (reprint from Comic Buyer's Guide) -- 6. A Night On the Town (reprint from Swords of Cerebus #6) -- 7. Cerebus Dreams (reprint from Swords of Cerebus #5) -- 8. Untitled
name: Cerebus World Tour Book 1995

person_credits.name: Dave Sim
person_credits.role: writer, penciler, letterer, inker, colorist, cover

description: In the Maxx story, Sara thinks about her sexual identity.
name: The Maxx

description: Island Uprising starring The Sandman, script by Larry Dean, art by Bert Christman; The Sandman rescues a girl from natives on an isle in the South Seas, then prevents the massacre of her father and his party. The Return of Fang Gow: Part 1 starring Barry O'Neill, script and art by Ed Winiarski; The Deadly Cough Medicine starring the Federal Men, script by Jerry Siegel, art by Wayne Boring. The Poor Fish starring Professor Doolittle, script and art by Bob Kane. The Flying Dutchman: Part 4 starring Socko Strong, script and art by Joseph Sulman (signed as Koppy). Count Ogrloff's Dangerous Game: Part 1 starring Captain Desmo, script and art by Ed Winiarski. The Devil's Physician--Anchors Aweigh!, script and art by Bart Tumey. The General's Daughter starring Skip Schuyler, script and art by Tom Hickey. The Menace of Chen Fu: Part 3 starring Rusty and His Pals, script and art by Bob Kane. The Revolt of the Pirates starring Cotton Carver, script by Gardner F. Fox, art by Ogden Whitney.
name: Island Uprising

description: The lovely Raven Hex's origin is re-told in much more detail here with this issue. We learn of the "Cup Of Shadows", and the important role it had in shping Raven into the Dark Witch we know and love today! Also the markings on Raven's body are fully explained!
name: The Dark Path

volume.name: Tarot: Witch of the Black Rose

description: The Sandman Meets the Face, script by Gardner F. Fox (sign as Larry Dean), pencils by Creig Flessel, inks by Creig Flessel and Fred Guardineer (backgrounds); The near victim of an old-friend turned crook, Wes Dodds watches him shot dead by the Face, then changes to the Sandman to discover why the villain had it in for the young victim. The Return of Fang Gow: Part 2 starring Barry O'Neill, script and art by Ed Winiarski. Mr. Fletcher, Smuggler starring Federal Men, script by Jerry Siegel, art by Mart Bailey. The Two Mr. Rowes starring Socko Strong, script and art by Joseph Sulman (signed as Koppy). Count Ogrloff's Dangerous Game: Part 2 starring Captain Desmo, script and art by Ed Winiarski. Search For Captain Wade: Part 1 starringSkip Schuyler, script and art by Tom Hickey. The Menace of Chen Fu: Part 4 starring Rusty and His Pals, script and art by Bob Kane. Alcatraz Al--Anchors Aweigh!, script and art by Bart Tumey. The Magnetic Peril starring Cotton Carver, script by Gardner F. Fox, art by Ogden Whitney.
name: The Sandman Meets The Face

description:
Many elements define the Spirit, but one of the more glamorous is definitely his femmes fatales! In this special issue, featuring spectacular stories from some of the industry's finest creators, discover a bevy of deadly new beauties!

In One Hundred!, some thugs dressed up as the Spirit on Halloween steal 100 blue azure diamonds. Walking through the zoo, the real Spirit puts a stop to their getaway. In the midst of the struggle, the pouch of diamonds lands in a tiger's cage. The only one that can get the diamonds is tiger tamer, Felicia Stripe. But what is she really after?

In Family Treasure, the Spirit helps an elderly woman from East Klovonia named Sonia find the hidden treasure her uncle left before he died.

In The Cold Depths of the Icicle Heart, the Spirit takes on an "ice queen" in a silent tale written by Gail Simone and drawn by Phil Hester and Ande Parks.
name: One Hundred!; Family Treasure; The Cold Depths of the Icicle Heart

description: The Golden Gusher starring The Sandman, script by Gardner F. Fox, art by Creig Flessel; A female singer is threatened to be kidnapped, but Sandman discovers she is in on the plot to do so in order to fleece an insurance company. Little Willie humor page by Bob Kane. Fang Gow Has Risen From the Grave: Part 1 starring Barry O'Neill, script and art by Ed Winiarski. In Hollywood starring Professor Doolittle, script and art by Bob Kane. Rutska the Racketeer starring the Federal Men, script by Jerry Siegel, art by Mart Bailey. Odds Bodkins's Big Score starring Socko Strong, script and art by Joseph Sulman (signed as Koppy). The Cholera Crisis starring Captain Desmo, script and art by Ed Winiarski. Search For Captain Wade: Part 2 starring Skip Schuyler, script and art by Tom Hickey. The Menace of Chen Fu: Part 5 starring Rusty and His Pals, script and art by Bob Kane. Satan's Sister--Anchors Aweigh!, script and art by Bart Tumey. Rebellion! starring Cotton Carver, script by Gardner F. Fox, art by Ogden Whitney.
name: The Golden Gusher

description: The Sandman Meets With Murder, script by Gardner F. Fox, art by Ogden Whitney; Wes Dodds fins his old room-mate from college dead and his wife also dead in an adjoining room, but is surprised, as the Sandman, when a girl identical to buddie's wife comes onto the murder scene. Fang Gow Has Risen From the Grave: Part 2 starring Barry O'Neill, script and art by Ed Winiarski. Professor Doolittle humor two-pager by Bob Kane. The Crooked Stockbroker starring the Federal Men, script by Jerry Siegel, art by Mart Bailey. The Heavyweight Championship Bout starring Socko Strong, script and art by Joseph Sulman (signed as Koppy). The Gold Plane Robberies: Part 1 starring Captain Desmo, script and art by Ed Winiarski. The Kidnapping of Linda Hale starring Skip Schuyler, script and art by Tom Hickey. Mansion of Murder: Part 1 starring Rusty and His Pals, art by Bob Kane. Educated Eddie--Anchors Aweigh!, script and art by Bart Tumey. In the Land of Sere starring Cotton Carver, script and art by Ogden Whitney.
name: The Sandman Meets with Murder

description:
From the files of the Secret Justice Team comes a tale of derring-do and action-packed action, as Captain Yesterday (Fry), Clobberella (Leela), and Super King (Bender) face the vengeful wrath of the spawn of one of the greatest villains from their decidedly small Rogues Gallery, The Sun!

Zodberg is dressed up in as a superhero and is calling himself, The Claw. He's trying out for the "New Justice" team made up of Captain Yesterday (Fry), Clobberella (Leela) and Super King (Bender). They tell him he's not good enough. Trying to show they what he can do, he accidentally cuts off Super King's head.

It turns out Bender was merely dreaming this. Fry is trying to wake him up. He tells Fry that he actually wasn't dreaming but remembering, for some reason, the time they were all superheroes. He got a new flash card and Fry notices that it says it's a "flashback memory card." Bender says he needs to pay more attention when he's stealing stuff. Fry wishes he could remember more. The miracle cream that gave them their powers had the side-effect of memory loss. Bender tells him he can project the memory onto the wall and begins replaying the memories.

Captain Yesterday and Clobberella go outside with the Professor when suddenly night becomes daylight. A flying flaming man arrives to see them. Captain Yesterday recognizes him as the Human Sun. He corrects him and tells him the Human Sun was his father and they're the ones that put him in jail. He is...the Son of the Sun.

Son of the Sun begins blazing and heating things up. Hermes runs out and recites the statute that decrees villains are required to give out their secret origins. Son of the Sun agrees.

His father, the Human Sun, was a crook but wasn't very successful at it. Son of the Sun was raised in his care and taught the ways of being a super-villain. Clobberella asks if he wants to free his father but Son of the Sun says no because they didn't really get along. But he still wants to have revenge on the world. He has created five mini-suns that are orbiting the Earth at that moment.

Things are heating up all over. Even President Nixon's head is beginning to boil in his jar. Captain Yesterday says it's time for them to do something. Super King doesn't feel like it until he hears Captain Yesterday mention being rewarded with endorsements including malt liquor.

They begin battling Son of the Sun but heat begins making them see things. Fry seems to be having a sunstroke and is envisioning a world where everyone looks like characters from Ronald McDonald's world. Son of the Sun decides to leave them all to die.

The world is heating over and the New Justice team can't do anything about it since they cannot go to Son of the Sun's base on the sun. The Professor then comes in and tells them about his new invention, the Nimbus 50000, a supercharged portable air conditioner. It projects a force field within twenty feet of it.

They journey to the sun and soon enter Son of the Sun's lair. Soon they are captured and are tied up in a deathtrap. He is about to leave them in never-ending daylight when Clobberella mentions that it seems like he really hates the dark. It turns out he is. His father kept him in constant light and the dark is just creepy to him. They begin to tell him the positive sides of darkness like romance, theft and a good night's sleep. Thinking that perhaps he's been wrong about darkness, they soon are at a nightclub. He thanks them for steering him clear on the awesomeness of the night.

The memory is over. Fry and Bender both miss being superheros. They decide to do it again, but in video game form. Hermes comes in and yells at them that they should be scrubbing the Planet Express ship.
name: Son of the Sun

description: This the second in the three-comic 'mini-series' of the official 'Encyclopedia' to the Tick Universe. Each issue features 1 to 3-page long write-ups about various important characters who have appeared in Tick and Tick-related comics. Issue 1 covers the letters P through Z.

volume.name: The Tick's Giant Circus of the Mighty

description: This comic may have the answers to all the questions you've been asking about The Tick and his Mom! Does the Tick have a Mom? Well, yes, he does. Why do "The Devolved Ticks" think The Tick is their Mom? Does The Tick have any maternal instincts? Does Author's mom approve if his super-hero career? Will The Tick's Big Mother's Day Special #1 make the ultimate Mother's Day gift for your Mom? Well, then how about you? Â
name: And Then There Were Three... Er... Two...

description: It's Halloween Day in The City, and The Tick and Arthur are shopping for a pumpkin to carve into a jack-o-lantern. Much to their shock, they discover that the local farmstand has been overrun with living pumpkins! These sinister jack-o-lanterns pull their roots out of the ground, grin sinisterly, and crawl about attacking the good citizens of The City! They want a leader... and there just happens to be a prized 500-pound pumpkin on display at the Annual Tri-County Fair! Can The Tick and Arthur stop these melons of menace? And what of the U.S.D.A. Extension Agent? Will he help or hinder our heroes? Find out in "The Orange Teeth of Horror!" Â
name: The Orange Teeth of Horror

description:
The Conclusion to the Revelations Story Arc. Ghost Rider is an Angel now and he's going up against the very last Lucifer Avatar's.

Be careful Johnny.
name: Revelations, Part 6: Conclusion

description: The Tick and Arthur decide to go "house-hunting" in the country. Little do they know that the house they settle on turns out to be haunted! Features a special appearance by The Red Eye, among other ghostly types. Includes the typical Tick tradition of spicy horror mixed with zany humor, what more could you want for Halloween? Â
name: Haunted Halloween Hootenanny

description: Accompanying the Circus Maximum Giant Edition, this all-new comic updates the giant "Tick Encyclopedia" right through all Tick comics published into the beginning of 2003. Between the Giant Edition and the Update 2003, Tick fans will have all the info they need on every character who has appeared from 1986 to 2003! Â

The Tick: Circus Maximus is the official encyclopedia of The Tick's comic book universe. This issue updates 1999's four-issue series, which covered all characters appearing in The Tick through 1999. Well, The Tick Universe grows every year, and so NEC offers this "21st Century Update" providing coverage of all characters introduced in the Year 2000, up-to-the-minute updates for major characters, and corrections of minor errors in the first four issues of Circus Maximus... along with a handful of characters missed in 1999's Circus Maximus issues. Â

This four-issue monthly limited series begins with the new millennium!

40-page black-and-white comic (no ads!) with full color covers. First of a four-issue monthly limited series. Text and art by the entire NEC Press creative crew of artists and writers. NEW material by Sean Wang... Bryant Johnson... Dave Garcia... Gabe Crate... Tak Toyoshima... Marc Silvia... Clay & Susan Griffith... Mike Oeming... Nathan MacDicken... Marc Sandroni... Christopher Scott Fields and others!

THE TICK CIRCUS MAXIMUS is the updated new edition of THE TICK'S GIANT CIRCUS OF THE MIGHTY... which was the original 'encyclopedia' of The Tick Universe. But it came out way back in 1992-1993 and is now almost EIGHT YEARS OLD! Time for an update!

THE TICK CIRCUS MAXIMUS is a completely revised and updated version of the classic but aging 'CIRCUS OF THE MIGHTY.' The four issues of the new series (160 pages total with NO ads!) will cover nearly THREE HUNDRED different 'entities' (heroes... villains... organizations... buildings... 'ordinary people'... etc.) who have appeared in any Tick Universe comic between 1986 and 1999. That's 13 years of coverage! Each article will feature newly revised text accompanied with updated artwork. THE TICK CIRCUS MAXIMUS will include loads of all-new artwork created by our Tick artists... as well as classic scenes from the original comics. There are lots of reasons why every Tick fan will want to buy THE TICK CIRCUS MAXIMUS:

Detailed articles on nearly 300 Tick Universe characters!

Artwork for nearly every entry; much of it brand new!

Lots of interesting and useful 'stats' included... such as 'first appearance'... 'super-hero-ness'... 'current status'... height... weight... hair and more!

Detailed cross-references to related entries!

Detailed references to appearances in the comics - by issue and page !

Includes 'sneak preview' info providing hints toward future Tick stories!

Many more surprises!

THE TICK CIRCUS MAXIMUS is sure to be a big hit for the Year 2000!
name: A thru D

description:
1. "Clark Kent's Super-Son!" Part 1 "The Brat of Steel!" Part 2 "Once There Was a Superman!": written by Otto Binder, penciled by Curt Swan and inked by George Klein. The story continues in Superman #194.
  2. "Cap's Hobby Hints How to do it Better" by Henry Boltinoff.

The Justice League of America makes a cameo appearance.
name: Clark Kent's Super-Son!

description:
First, Lisa goes on a game show in order to settle a bet with Bart and capture Homer's attention. But when she gets sick, Lisa discovers that cold medicine is the great intellectual equalizer. Then, Milhouse decides its time to learn how to defend himself by taking karate classes. Finally, another Professor Frink invention in Bart's hands gives Maggie the ability to fly!

  1. ...Who Wants To Win A Pocketful Of Quarters? (Lisa wants to prove she can win on a TV game show. Can she compete against martin and Ralph?)
  2. Quantum Cola (Professor Frink's Partly Probable Parables : Maggie gets superpowers)
  3. Bully For You! (Milhouse takes judo lessons)
  4. Bart's People (letters and fan art)
name: Juvenile Jokester

description:
Lola Bunny is back! The Looney lady with an attitude kicks off a new life of adventure by delivering pizza to Atlantis -and becoming the terror of the deep when Atlantis won't pay up!

  1. Sea Monkey Business (Lola Bunny delivers pizza to ... Atlantis?!?)
  2. Foes Afloat (Sylvester, Tweety)
  3. Rabbit Seasoning (Bugs Bunny, Taz the Tasmanian Devil, Foghorn Leghorn, Daffy Duck)
name: Lola Bunny's Back

description:
The Justice Society of America star in "The Plunder of the Psycho-Pirate."

A new foe confronts the Justice Society - the Psycho Pirate - and it isn't long before he is pulling the strings and the JSA are dancing to his tune. Can the heroes break his hold on them and use their powers to overcome him? The Spectre and Starman leave the JSA with this issue.

1. Cover by Curt Swan and Neal Adams.
  2. "The Unbreakable Spell!" (part 1) "The Chestnut Mare Ain't What She Used to Be!" (part 2) written by E. Nelson Bridwell, penciled by Curt Swan and inked by Mike Esposito.

"Great Krypton! A magic spell has turned Lois into a centaur! She'll never be human again!"
name: The Unbreakable Spell!

description: "A long-lost nemesis of the Bat returns to exact revenge for a painful personal loss while someone poses as Batman in a public place! Plus, the return of the Joker!"
name: War Crimes, Part 2 of 4: Minor Discrepancies

description:
1. Secret of the Time Creature (Superman, Batman and Robin / written by Bill Finger : "Great Scott, Batman! Even Superman Is bouncing off the force-wall around that creature!")
  2. Shorty (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  3. It's Fun To Help Others (public service message by Superboy / written by Jack Schiff)
  4. The Planeteer Film Star (Tommy Tomorrow, Brent Wood / written by Jack Miller)
  5. Playful Pop (humor)
  6. The Invisible Ally (full text story)
  7. The Menace Of The Mole Men (Green Arrow, Speedy / written by Ed Herron)
name: Secret of the Time Creature

description:
1. Superboy's Two Rivals (Superboy, Ma and Pa Kent)
  2. Family Projects can be Fun! (public service message by Binky / written by Jack Schiff)
  3. Superboy, Stowaway! (Superboy, Lana Lang, Professor Lang / written by Otto Binder)
  4. Shorty (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  5. The Fastest Thing on Earth (full text article by Jack Miller)
  6. Peg (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
  7. The Gaucho of Smallville! (Superboy : "He's lassoed himslf instead of the bull, with his own bolas!")
  8. Weather Guide (Superboy's Workshop)
name: The Gaucho of Smallville!

description: 1. The Mystery of the Canine Champ (Jimmy Olsen, Superman, Lois Lane, Perry White / written by Otto Binder) -- 2. The Big Dance (full text public service message written by Jack Schiff) -- 3. Jimmy Olsen, Speed Demon (Jimmy Olsen, Superman, Lois, Perry : "It's a rocket!" "It's Superman!" "No...it's Jimmy Olsen! and he's got my super-speed!") -- 4. Little Morton (gag strip by Phil Berube) -- 5. Daffy & Doodle (gag strip) -- 6. Unwanted Superman Souvenirs (Jimmy Olsen, Superman) -- 7. Varsity Vic (gag strip by Henry Boltinoff)
name: Jimmy Olsen, Speed Demon

description:
Overview

It's all-out war as the Challengers find Ray Palmer - and so does everyone else! The fate of a universe hangs in the balance, as heroes and villains from across the multiverse face betrayal and death with Earth as their battlefield!

Plus, more DC Villains origin backup stories, including The Origin of Cyborg Superman by Scott Beatty and Ivan Reis!
name: Abandon All Hope

description: 1. A Note From The Publisher -- 2. Petuniacon ... Day Two (Cerebus) -- 3. Welcome To Heaven, Dr. Franklin Part 5 (by William Messner- Loebs) -- 4. Aardvark Comment
name: Petuniacon ... Day Two

person_credits.name: Dave Sim
person_credits.role: writer, penciler, letterer, inker, colorist, cover

description:
It's all-out war as the Challengers find Ray Palmer - and so does everyone else! The fate of a universe hangs in the balance, as heroes and villains from across the multiverse face betrayal and death with Earth as their battlefield!

Plus, more DC Villains origin backup stories, including The Origin of Doomsday by Scott Beatty and Jon Bogdanove!
name: Splitting the Atom

description:
1. Holy Cow!! Has Pieman Turned Evil? ("Witness the cream-filled fury of Pieman (a.k.a. Homer Simpson) when an evil doppelganger seeks to tarnish his indignant and indulgent identity!" starring Pieman and the Cupcake Kid)
  2. The Crimespree on Springfield 2! ("Follow Bartman and Houseboy (Bart/Milhouse) into a parallel world when they find themselves in the bizarrely-altered world of Shelbyville" starring Bartman and Houseboy)
  3. The Origin of Radioactive Man
  4. The Little Boy with the Big Dream
  5. Roargo
name: Holy Cow!! Has Pieman Turned Evil?

description:
Rotting James Robinson (Starman, Earth 2) tells of Springfieldians who become ferociously feline in a flesh-tearing little foray called "Bart People." Alarming Mike Allred (Madman, iZombie) turns the screws on a screaming story of botany and gluttony gone awry called "Little Shop of Homers." And, Jaundiced Jeff Smith (Bone, RASL) stirs the brew with a whiteknuckled whale's tale entitled "Call Me Homer." Three scarifying stories to whet your nocturnal appetite! But be forewarned: These grim tales may cause you to laugh yourself to DEATH!

Chapter Titles

  1. Little Shop of Homers (Mike Allred / Bill Morrison)
  2. Call Me Homer (Jeff Smith / Stephanie Gladden)
  3. Bart People (James Robinson / Chris Roman)

  4. 49 Things that Frightened and Disturbed Me When I Was a Kid (full text article by Matt Groening)
name: Little Shop of Homers; Call Me Homer; Bart People

description: Zerb and Rising Stars haunt Top Cow! Lionel Zerb can see dead people. Always considered the freak in the Rising Stars universe, Zerb's story has largely gone overlooked...until now. As a direct conduit to the dead, Zerb opens an agency as a Ghost Interpreter, helping people deal with hauntings and other "spirit" cases. But one day, Zerb stumbles upon a force greater than he ever imagined. Lionel must confront an ancient spiritual power that brings him near death, but closer to an understanding about the mysteries of the universe. Â
name: Voices of the Dead #1

volume.name: Rising Stars: Voices Of The Dead

description:
Overview

Conan finds himself embroiled in a political struggle turned bloody between a naive young prince and a sinister sorcerer who calls upon the god of the underworld to help aid him in building an army of demonic abominations, intent on conquering not just his own kingdom, but all of Hyboria! But that's not the only danger that threatens to destroy Conan's world. Little does he know, a piece of his past still follows him, stalking the Cimmerian with the patience of the grave. All roads lead to the doomed city of Yaralet in this stunning adaptation of Robert E. Howard's lost fragment "The Hand of Nergal."
name: Darkness Rising
